title: NHS in crisis as spending at its worst rate since 1950s as Tories fail to fund it
text:
NHS in crisis as spending at its worst rate since 1950s as Tories fail to fund it Millions of patients are suffering the longest ever waits for casualty care, beds, cancer treatment and operations Share The NHS is facing a cash crisis (Photo: Liverpool Echo) Share Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
With the NHS collapsing around her ears, brazen Theresa May has insisted the Tories had lavished record sums of cash on the service. 
But figures unearthed by the Mirror shatter that claim as they show spending is growing at the slowest rate since records began in 1955 – and it is likely to stay that way until the end of the decade. 
Millions of patients are suffering the longest ever waits for casualty care, beds, cancer treatment and operations. 
And experts the blame Government NHS spending, which now stands at a measly annual growth rate of 1.1%. 
Independent economic forecaster the IFS, which provided the figures, said the shocking funding crisis gripping the NHS means it will be unable to cope with our population growth and ageing population. Read More Babies waiting on floor and pensioners on trolleys for 14 hours: The reality of life in A&E under Theresa May Spending levels are at their worst rates since the 1950s (Photo: Alamy) 
Mrs May is facing growing ­criticism over the dangerous lack of cash that is starving the service and putting thousands of lives at risk. 
And she was accused of denying there was any crisis, despite the almost daily accounts of patients waiting for hours on trollies, bed blocking due to lack of social care and cancelled operations. 
Shadow Health Secretary Jon Ashworth said: “The experts at the IFS confirm what we’ve been warning now for some time. 
“The NHS is going through the biggest financial squeeze in its history. Every day we see an NHS pushed to the brink because of Tory underfunding. 
“These are some of the worst figures we have seen. Experts are saying ­standards are being pushed back 15 years or more. “ Labour are calling for Theresa May to get a grip (Photo: Getty) 
This can’t carry on. Theresa May needs to get a grip, give the NHS the ­investment it needs. 
“Behind each of these statistics is a patient suffering. It’s making Theresa May’s utter disregard for the dire state of the NHS all the more disgraceful.” 
British Medical ­Association chair Dr Mark Porter added: “The ­Government has failed to grasp the seriousness of the ­situation. 
"The Prime Minister cannot continue to bury her head in the sand as care worsens.” 
The IFS report said: “The period between 2009/10 and 2014/15 saw ­historically slow increases in public spending on health, averaging 1.1% a year. 
“This was the lowest five-year growth rate since a consistent time series of health spending began in 1955/56.” This rate of growth is even smaller than the last Tory government between 1979 and 1997 under Margaret Thatcher and John Major (Photo: Getty) 
This rate of growth is even smaller than the last Tory government between 1979 and 1997 under Margaret Thatcher and John Major - when the rate averaged 3.4%. 
Labour PMs Tony Blair and Gordon Brown oversaw growth of 5.9%. 
Separate figures leaked to the BBC showed record numbers of patients, at least 780, spent more than four hours waiting in A&E in January. 
Only 82% were ­transferred, admitted or discharged within that time. The target is 95%. It appeared to be the worst month in the past 13 years. 
The figures also suggest record numbers of people, more than 60,000, waited longer than 12 hours for a bed once seen. 
Labour MP Heidi Alexander, who sits on the Commons Health Committee, said: "We just can't go on as we are. We have got more people waiting for hours to be seen in A&E, more people waiting longer for important operations, and more people stuck in hospital when they're well enough to go home. 
"Simon Stevens at the Public Accounts Committee in January was quite open about the fact that spending per head of the population is going to go down next year, and at the very least funding has to keep up with demand. 
"We've got about 5million more people living in the UK over the last 10 years and more of those people are older. The number of people over the age of 85 is expected to roughly double over the next 20 years. 
"So we have to find a solution to this and I just think the government have put their head in the sand about it." 
New data shows 2,593 people waited more than 12 hours to be admitted in 2016 – the highest ever and more than double the 1,206 in the previous year. A record number of people are waiting to be treated (Photo: Getty) 
Delays to cancer treatment are also causing more people to suffer anxiety and depression. In 2016, 25,157 waited for more than two months, another sickening and unwelcome record. 
Macmillan Cancer Support’s Dr Fran Woodard said: “This is a stark warning sign that services are struggling to keep up with demand. These pressures will only become more acute as the numbers of people diagnosed increases.” 
The number of patients blocking beds due to lack of social care was also the highest on record last year. 
Dr Chris Moulton, vice-president of The Royal College of Emergency Medicine, said: “We simply do not have any more room to put patients. 
“We have the lowest number of acute beds per capita in Europe. As a result, bed occupancy is at dangerous levels and exit block is putting lives at risk.” 
NHS Providers, which represents ­hospitals, has called for an urgent review of winter pressures on the health service. How the UK compares to Europe UK population aged 65 and over The health spending slowdown NHS Spending 2015-16 
Chief executive Chris Hopson said: “NHS staff have responded magnificently to increased winter pressures, but the situation has become unsustainable. 
“The rise in long trolley waits is ­particularly worrying, as there is evidence they can lead to worse outcomes for patients.” 
Other figures showed almost three-quarters of hospitals have had patients wait for more than 100 days to be discharged – even though fit to leave. 
Despite the ­overwhelming evidence the NHS is at breaking point, arrogant Mrs May kept up the pretence that all was well under the Tories. 
She said: “We have put record funding into the National Health Service. I recognise it is under pressure, that’s why we will be putting the £10billion extra in. 
“We are seeing something like 3,000 more people being seen within the four-hour standard every day in the NHS.” 
The UK forks out less on health than other EU countries. In 2014, the latest figures which are available, total health spending accounted for 9.9% of GDP. 
But the average in Europe was 10.3%, according to the Nuffield Trust. 
Germany spent 11% of GDP on health and France 11.1%. Like us on Facebook
